author: txtiger
content: <@881905303011086387> Does EIP-6404 (https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/commit/c819006033b6b344fd87f86f64d982da311d1b80) now handle EIP-7932esk algorithms natively? If so would it be worth linking to 7932 for the algorithm registry and me moving EIP-7932 to be RLP-only, at least for the wrapper tx?

author: etan_status
content:
true, 6404 advanced a bit into that direction, indeed (based on feedback from danno ferin)! It combines `algorithm_type`+ `signature_info` into a single `ProgressiveList[byte]` though. this could also be applied to existing transaction types (as in, anywhere where a signature is present, could just give it a different prefix). for signature algos that don't support something like ecrecover, one could also just put the pubkey into the signature as well (it's opaque after all). it's also possible to have sub-algo types (it doesn't have to be 1-byte prefix, can also be longer, if needed).

in your eip the 7932 `additional_signatures` probably should be a `ProgressiveList[AdditionalSignature]` to reduce hashcount at low signature counts (otherwise you end up hashing the full 256 capacity tree), and then just have `MAX_ADDITIONAL_INFO` as a validation rule. what is the usage here, is it for nested authorizations in 7702 transactions? if that's the case, with 6404 it's possible to just apply the algos to the inner signatures as well, rather than "overriding" them in a wrapper.

Also, applied feedback to move away from `identify_transaction_profile` to a SSZ CompatibleUnion.
The `assets/eip-6404` folder in EIPs repo contains some executable Python tests, btw (`convert_tests.py`), if you want to make sure the SSZ type actually works out.

btw in 7932 the `compute_ssz_sig_hash` in 7932 is actually pulling in 6493 as well (6404 initially only proposes a way to represent RLP txes as SSZ)

Regarding the actual registry, I think it makes sense to have it separate from 6404 so it can be maintained as a living doc. In case 6404 gets accepted, I guess 7932 would _become_ the registry EIP (as then we don't need RLP). Otherwise, EIP-7932 would be RLP-only, and EIP-6404 would have to find a way to represent it in the SSZ world.

author: txtiger
content:
Thanks for the reply,

If we make 7932 transactions RLP only, we'd still have the `sigrecover` precompile, gas accounting mechanics, address recovery and the algorithm registry. 

I wanted to remove SSZ support, at least for the wrapper, because once SSZ becomes the prevalent TX type, and signatures are `ExecutionSignature`, `ExecutionSignatureAlgorithm` pairs. There wouldn't be any need for the wrapper anymore, so it would not make sense to keep it around. As we could just use the 7932 registry and the `secp256k1` algorithm that is already defined.

author: txtiger
content: There is also the ML-DSA draft which implements 7932 support: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/10557/files#diff-788a7f8fe28526e767a1c2c716503f6e4bf565a4925dc3ba42964ffaf4d68a01R201

author: etan_status
content:
Yeah, I think getting rid of the SSZ wrapper would be beneficial! While keeping the note that the RLP wrapper is only needed in a non-6404 world.

Is it possible to make the 7932 registry compatible with the 6404 impl? I think including the algorithm as a prefix into the signature is fine, there's not really a point in giving the algo its separate field (extra hash cost, and limited to uint8).

author: etan_status
content: Then can just link to the 7932 registry from 6404, as you proposed

author: etan_status

author: txtiger
content: As in the current `secp256k1` impl in 6404 would work with 7932?

author: etan_status
content: I mean more like, including `algorithm_type` as a prefix into `signature_info`, so that the entire signature is just an opaque blob rather than a pair of two things (of which `algorithm_type` is restricted to uint8)

author: etan_status
content: advantage is, could extend the registry with subtypes in the future, without breaking the data type schema

author: txtiger
content: That does seem like a better idea and is surprisingly not that much of a change
